ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How right wing ideology spreads. Putting a harmful message in context. What drives people to extremism.
I learned about analyzing content from the far-right: using my understanding of code-words and sentence structures to figure out the ideology--and maybe even the intentions--of the person posting.
Learned about right-wing extremism, conspiracy theories, terrorism, and radicalization.
I was able to gain a better understanding of how right wing movements develop, and what form they take in our current society as well as how they've evolved over time.
I gained the ability to understand historical and contemporary far-right and antisemitic groups and movements, and to analyze and identify social media posts, symbols, and literature of these groups.
I learned so much about current antisemitism / right wing extremism. I feel like I have a much stronger understanding of the current issues that we face and how pervasive they are in society.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strength is it is ultra-insightful at the beginning and I became genuinely interested in the topic outside class. The weakness was organization. It was often hard to find the readings, and some weren't uploaded until much later in the semester.
The readings, the discussions, the exam/midterm were so engaging and so interesting-- difficult emotionally, and challenging academically, but in a good way I would not change.
The class was mostly lecture based, might be better in the form of a lecture rather than a seminar.
No rubrics, unclear grading scale, not a lot of grades that go into the gradebook. Interesting content but professor's political views got in the way often.

A strength is the hands-on approach to looking at far-right online content and learning to understand it. An area of improvement is that it would be nice for students to talk about the readings in class.

I loved this course. I think that there could have been more opportunities for grades so that it didnt rely as heavily on the final and midterm. I also think a paper would have sufficed instead of an exam.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you are interesting in these dynamics of radicalization.

This class was a tremendous joy. I do not think I have ever been as engaged by course content before. Professor Koblentz-Stenzler led some of the most empathetic and thoughtful conversations I have ever taken part in, which was remarkable considering the weight of the subject matter. Yale does not have many seminars that work to really understand other people -- especially those at the fringes of society. I am so glad this is being taught. One of the interesting components was most people in the class had a personal connection to the far-right (usually family members who have fallen for conspiracy theories), which made for an admirable and uncommon level of empathy and perspective in the room. Professor Koblentz-Stenzler was clearly captured and engaged by every point made by students, which was so incredibly encouraging. This class is a must take. 

This course was not easy. By that, I do not mean the grading was unfair. I mean that the content was really hard. We were warned of this. But the midterm project, which required investigating a far-right group, was a sobering experience. It was one of the most emotionally challenging things I have ever done. I am so much stronger for it -- but I just want other students to know: Expect to be challenged in this way. I admire the strength of everyone in that class.

Yes! Liram is an incredibly insightful lecturer, and she made it worthwhile to come to seminar each week. The class had immediate applications to the political sphere of Fall 2023: Liram adapted some of the lectures to give more context to the Israel-Hamas war, and her treatment of the material was level-handed and quite informative. I came out of the class with a far more in-depth understanding of extremist movements than one could glean from the NYT or WSJ, and it'll greatly help inform my viewpoint on modern politics.
I think the content of this class is incredibly interesting , but i think it's logistical shortcomings are enough of a reason to not take this class.

I would absolutely recommend this course! No matter what your major is, it's important to be a smart consumer of online content and be able to identify content that seems harmless but is connected to far-right and antisemitic groups.
Yes I would. It is important
